name: Defend - Configuring Unified Quarantine with Microsoft Defender for Office 365
title: Defend - Configuring Unified Quarantine with Microsoft Defender for Office 365
body:
Overview

This guide details the steps to set up unified quarantine between KnowBe4's Inbound Mail Security and Microsoft Defender for Office 365. The configuration enables email remediation from user inboxes to Microsoft's quarantine system using the Set Verdict API. Once configured, you can automatically apply specific Microsoft Defender for Office 365 phishing actions and quarantine policies to emails based on KnowBe4 Defend's Inbound Mail Security analysis.

This configuration is achieved through our Unified Quarantine feature, which maps KnowBe4 Defend's phishing verdicts to the corresponding Microsoft Defender for Office 365's phishing verdicts:

KnowBe4 Defend Phishing Verdicts Microsoft Defender for Office 365 Phishing Verdicts
High Confidence Phish High Confidence Phish
Dangerous Phish Phish

Prerequisites

Make sure that your environment meets our basic requirements listed below:

    • Microsoft 365 admin account with appropriate permissions
    • Microsoft P2 license
    • KnowBe4 Inbound Mail Security linked with a Microsoft 365 Admin app registration and configured to send phishing verdicts to Microsoft

Configuration Instructions

Follow the configuration instructions below to set up KnowBe4 Defend and Microsoft Defender for Office 365 to create a unified quarantine experience.

Setting up KnowBe4 Defend for Unified Quarantine

The steps below show how to set up KnowBe4 Defend's Inbound Mail Security for unified quarantine with Microsoft Defender for Office 365.

  1. Sign in to the KnowBe4 Security Center.
  2. Expand the Defend menu on the left side of the console.
  3. Click Settings.

  4. Scroll down to the Quarantine section.
  5. In the Pre Delivery Quarantine section, select Do not send to Microsoft quarantine in the drop-down menu.
  6. In the Post Delivery Quarantine section, select Enabled in the drop-down menu.

Accessing the Anti-Spam Policies in Microsoft 365

The steps below show how to access the Anti-spam policies in Microsoft Defender for Office 365.

  1. Sign in to the Microsoft Defender for Office 365 portal.
  2. Navigate to Email & collaboration > Policies & rules > Threat policies.

  3. Under the Policies section, click on the Anti-spam policy.

Modifying an Existing or Creating a New Anti-Spam Inbound Policy

Follow the steps in Option 1 or Option 2 below to configure your inbound anti-spam policy and determine what actions Microsoft Defender for Office 365 will take on phishing and high confidence phishing emails.

Option 1: Edit an Existing Policy

Follow the steps below to edit an existing inbound anti-spam policy.

  1. From the list of policies, select the inbound policy you want to modify.
  2. Double-click on the policy name to edit the policy.

  3. In the Actions menu on the right side of the page, scroll down and click Edit actions.

Option 2: Create a New Policy

Follow the steps below to create a new inbound anti-spam policy.

  1. Click on + Create policy.

  2. Select Inbound.

  3. Enter a Name for your policy, such as "KnowBe4 Inbound Mail Security Integration".

  4. Click Next.
Note:For additional information on configuring inbound anti-spam policies, see Microsoft's Configure anti-spam policies for cloud mailboxes article.

Configure Actions for Phishing Verdicts

Follow the steps below to configure actions for phishing verdicts.

  1. In the Actions section, click Edit actions.

  2. For the Phishing section, choose from these available message actions:
      • Move message to Junk Email folder
      • Add X-header
      • Prepend subject line with text
      • Redirect message to email address
      • Delete message
      • Quarantine message

  3. If you selected Quarantine message for the Phishing message action, select your preferred quarantine policy from the Select quarantine policy drop-down menu. Custom quarantine policies appear in the available options.

Configure Actions for High Confidence Phishing Verdicts

Follow the steps below to configure actions for high-confidence phishing verdicts.

  1. In the Actions section, click Edit actions.
  2. For the High confidence phishing section, choose from these available actions:
      • Quarantine message
      • Move message to Junk Email folder
      • Redirect message to email address

  3. If you selected Quarantine message for the High Confidence Phishing message action, select your preferred quarantine policy from the Select quarantine policy drop-down menu. Custom quarantine policies appear in the available options.

Save Your Changes

To save changes to your policy, follow the steps below:

  1. Review all your settings.
  2. Click Save or Next, depending on whether you're editing an existing policy or creating a new one.
  3. If creating a new policy, you may need to define additional settings like priority and user or domain scope before saving.
Important:Please ensure that ZAP is selected in the Microsoft Defender for Office 365 default policy actions; if it's not selected, you cannot send emails to quarantine or junk using KnowBe4's Inbound Mail Security Unified Quarantine feature.

Setting Up Quarantine Notifications for Users

If Quarantine message is selected for Phishing or High confidence phishing in your inbound anti-spam policy for Microsoft Defender for Office 365, you can select a quarantine policy to notify your users. There are several default quarantine policies that Microsoft Defender for Office 365 provides, or you can set up a custom quarantine policy. The sections below will show you how you can customize the existing quarantine policies or create your own custom policy.

Access Quarantine Notification Settings

The steps below will show you where you can access the quarantine policies in Microsoft Defender for Office 365:

  1. Sign in to the Microsoft Defender for Office 365 portal.
  2. Navigate to Email & collaboration > Policies & rules > Threat policies.

  3. Select Quarantine policies under the Rules section.

Configure Existing Quarantine Policies

The steps below show how you can configure existing quarantine policies.

  1. Click Global settings.

    Note:The Global Settings are the only way to edit the four default policies: NotificationEnabledPolicy, DefaultFullAccessPolicy, AdminOnlyAccessPolicy, and DefaultFullAccessWithNotificationPolicy.
  2. The menu that appears on the right side of the page allows you to customize the email notifications for your users:
      • Sender display name
      • Sender address
      • Subject
      • Disclaimer
      • Language
      • Company logo
      • Notification frequency
    Note:The only default quarantine policies that allow quarantine notifications for your users are the NotificationEnabledPolicy and the DefaultFullAccessWithNotificationPolicy. For additional information, see Microsoft's Use quarantine notifications to release and report quarantined messages article.

Create New Quarantine Policies

Follow the steps below to create and configure a new quarantine policy.

  1. Select +Add custom policy.
  2. Name your new quarantine policy.
  3. Select the preferred Recipient message access:
    • Limited access will allow users to view quarantine messages
    • Set specific access (Advanced) allows you to control the level of access your users have for quarantined messages

  4. Select the Enable check box to turn on quarantine notifications, and then select whether or not to include quarantined messages from blocked sender addresses.

  5. Review the following settings:
    • Tag name: This is the name of your new quarantine policy.
    • User message access: These are the actions that your users can take on quarantined messages.
    • Quarantine notification: Choose whether users will receive a notification when a message is sent to quarantine.

Save Your Configuration

Once you've configured your desired notification settings, click Save to apply the changes.

User Experience

When users receive a quarantine notification:

  1. The email will list messages that have been quarantined for them.
  2. Users can preview details about each quarantined message.
  3. Depending on your configuration, users may be able to:
    • Release or request release for messages they believe are legitimate
    • View the reason for quarantine
    • Delete message
    • Block sender
    • Allow sender

This image displays two sections detailing configuration settings and connection statuses within a software platform, utilizing a dark background for the UI.

**Section 1: Admin Features**

1.  **Header:** "Admin Features" (Bold white text).
2.  **Description:** "Unlocks the ability to view & remediate emails from within the platform."
3.  **Information Link:** "More details." (Blue hyperlink, inline with the description).
4.  **Status Indicator:** A green checkmark followed by the green text "Enabled," indicating successful activation and connection.
5.  **Action Hyperlink:** "Relink to Microsoft 365" (Blue text), suggesting a re-authentication option.

**Section 2: User Analysis**

1.  **Header:** "User Analysis" (Bold white text).
2.  **Description:** "Allows Defend to analyze users historical emails and mailbox details."
3.  **Information Link:** "More details." (Blue hyperlink, inline with the description).
4.  **Status Indicator:** A green checkmark followed by the green text "Enabled," indicating successful activation and connection.
5.  **Action Hyperlink:** "Relink to Microsoft 365" (Blue text), suggesting a re-authentication option.

images.alt:
This image displays the main dashboard of the **KnowBe4 Security Center**, presented against a dark-mode background.

**I. Header and Context:**
The main title centrally located on the right side of the screen is **"KnowBe4 Security Center."**

**II. Left Navigation Sidebar:**
The persistent left navigation menu features several security and administrative options, organized under collapsible sections:

*   **Top Level:** `Home`
*   **Module Header:** `Human Risk Management` (Collapsible)
*   **Section Header:** `Defend` (Expanded, indicated by an upward chevron)
    *   `Defend Dashboard`
    *   `Recent Emails`
    *   `Abuse Mailbox`
    *   `Allow / Deny lists`
    *   `Event Notifications`
    *   `Settings` (Highlighted in the current context, indicated by a gear icon)
    *   `URL Rewriting / Decode`
    *   `User Management`
    *   `Audit Log`
*   **Section Header:** `Prevent` (Collapsed, indicated by a downward chevron)

**III. Main Content Cards (Security Modules):**
Three prominent dark-themed feature cards are displayed horizontally, summarizing key security modules:

1.  **Module: Human Risk Management**
    *   **Description:** "Identify and manage human risk across your organization using an adaptive security model."
    *   **Status:** Enabled (Confirmed by a green checkmark icon).
    *   **Action Button:** `Dashboard` (with a chart icon).

2.  **Module: Defend**
    *   **Description:** "Detect advanced phishing attacks, including business email compromise, supply chain compromise, and account impersonation."
    *   **Status:** Purchased (Confirmed by a green checkmark icon).
    *   **Action Button:** `Dashboard` (with a chart icon).

3.  **Module: Prevent**
    *   **Description:** "Prevent outbound email data breaches, including misdirected emails and exfiltration."
    *   **Status:** Purchased (Confirmed by a green checkmark icon).
    *   **Action Button:** `Dashboard` (with a chart icon).

The image displays a section of a configuration interface, titled **Quarantine**, utilizing a dark UI theme. This section features two distinct configuration options, each presented as a label followed by a dropdown menu and a contextual help icon (question mark).

1.  **Pre Delivery Quarantine:** The label is "Pre Delivery Quarantine." The associated dropdown menu is currently set to the value: **Do not send to Microsoft quarantine**.
2.  **Post Delivery Quarantine:** The label is "Post Delivery Quarantine." The associated dropdown menu is currently set to the value: **Enabled**.

A large, diagonally positioned, orange arrow annotation is present, originating near the "Pre Delivery Quarantine" dropdown and pointing directly towards the "Enabled" value in the "Post Delivery Quarantine" dropdown.

This image displays the Microsoft Defender administrative portal, featuring a dark theme and a two-panel layout.

**Left Navigation Pane (Highlighted Context):**

1.  The primary navigation panel shows a menu hierarchy, with the top-level grouping **"Email & collaboration"** selected (indicated by an outline).
2.  Sub-menu items within this section include: Investigations, Explorer, Review, Campaigns, Threat tracker, Exchange message trace, and Attack simulation training.
3.  The specific sub-menu item currently active and viewing is **"Policies & rules"** (outlined, located near the bottom of the visible list).

**Main Content Panel (Policies & rules View):**

1.  **Title:** The page is titled **"Policies & rules"** in large, bold text.
2.  **Description:** A subtitle reads: "Set up policies to manage devices, protect against th[reats]."
3.  **Policy List:** The panel displays a list of available policy types under a "Name" column header (which includes a sort chevron).
4.  **Policy Links:** Two specific policy types are listed:
    *   **Threat policies** (Prominently outlined/highlighted).
    *   **Alert policy**

The image displays the **Threat policies** configuration screen within the Microsoft Defender portal interface (dark theme).

**Context and Navigation:**
The primary navigation pane (left sidebar) shows the "Email & collaboration" section expanded. The main content area is titled **Threat policies**.

**Content Structure:**
The policy configuration is divided into sections:

1.  **Templated policies:** Includes links for **Preset Security Policies** and **Configuration analyzer**.
2.  **Policies:** A list of configurable security policies for email and content.

**Detailed UI Elements (Policies Section):**
The list item **Anti-spam** is highlighted (indicated by a red bounding box in the context) and is associated with an envelope icon.

*   **Policy Name:** Anti-spam
*   **Description:** "Protect your organization's email from spam, including what actions to take if spam is detected"

Other visible policies in this section include:

*   **Anti-phishing:** (Description: Protects users from phishing and configures safety tips.)
*   **Anti-malware:** (Description: Protects email from malware, including action specification and notification settings.)
*   **Safe Attachments:** (Description: Protects against malicious content in email attachments and files across SharePoint, OneDrive, and Teams.)
*   **Safe Links:** (Description: Protects users from malicious links in email messages and Office apps.)

This image captures a dark-themed administration interface focused on **Anti-spam policies** within the path `Policies & rules > Threat policies`.

The screen is divided into two primary sections:

1.  **Policy List (Left Panel):** A table listing five security policies under `Name` and `Status` columns. The list includes `Strict Preset Security Policy` (Off), `Standard Preset Security Policy` (On), and three policies set to `Always on`. The policy **Anti-spam inbound policy (Default)** is currently selected, highlighted by a checked box and an orange pointer. Control buttons include `+ Create policy` and `Refresh`.

2.  **Details Pane (Right Flyout):** This panel displays the configuration summary for the selected policy, **Anti-spam inbound policy (Default)**. The status is listed as `Always on | Priority Lowest`. Configuration options are presented under collapsible headers:
    *   **Description:** Contains the sub-item `Bulk email threshold & spam properties`.
    *   **Actions:** Contains the sub-item `Allowed and blocked senders and domains`.

The sub-details under **Allowed and blocked senders and domains** show current counts:
*   Allowed senders: 4 senders
*   Allowed domains: 3 domains
*   Blocked senders: -
*   Blocked domains: -

A blue hyperlink, `Edit allowed and blocked senders and domains`, is available at the bottom of the details section, followed by a primary action button labeled `Close`.
images.context: click on the policy name to edit the policy.

images.alt:
This image displays the detail view for an anti-spam policy within a dark-mode administrative console.

**Context and Header:**
The page title is **Anti-spam inbound policy (Default)**, accompanied by a document/scroll icon. A subtitle, prefixed by a green status indicator, states **Always on | Priority Lowest**. Standard navigation controls (up/down arrows, close 'x') are visible in the top right corner.

**Policy Settings (Key/Value Pairs):**

| Setting Category | Field Name | Value |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Quarantine** | Quarantine message action | Quarantine message |
| | Apply the following quarantine policy | DefaultFullAccessWithNotificationPolicy |
| **Phishing** | High confidence phishing message action | Quarantine message |
| | Apply the following quarantine policy | DefaultFullAccessWithNotificationPolicy |
| **Bulk/Internal** | Bulk message action | Move message to Junk Email folder |
| | Intra-Organizational messages to take action on | Default |
| **Safety Tips** | Enable spam safety tips | On (Green indicator) |
| | Enable for spam messages | On (Green indicator) |
| | Enable for phishing messages | On (Green indicator) |
| **Retention** | Retain spam in quarantine for this many days | 30 |

**Action Element:**
At the bottom of the display, a button labeled **Edit actions** is visible and highlighted by an orange border, indicating a primary or focused interactive element.

This image displays the Microsoft Defender administrative portal using a dark theme, specifically focused on email security configuration.

**Context and Navigation:**
The top bar identifies the application as **Microsoft Defender**. The current page location is indicated by the breadcrumb: `Policies & rules > Threat policies > Anti-spam policies`. A vertical navigation pane on the left lists various security areas, including "Email & collaboration" and "Policies & rules" (currently highlighted).

**Main Content Area:**
The page title is **"Anti-spam policies"**. A descriptive text states: "Use this page to configure policies that are included in anti-spam protection. These policies include connection filtering, spam filtering, and [truncated]."

**Actionable UI Elements:**
Below the descriptive text are two primary action elements:
1.  A button/dropdown labeled **"+ Create policy"**.
2.  A refresh icon followed by the text **"Refresh"**.

**Data Table (Policy List):**
A table lists existing anti-spam policies with two columns: **Name** and **Status**. Policies listed include default and preset security configurations:

| Name | Status |
| :--- | :--- |
| Strict Preset Security Policy | Off |
| Standard Preset Security Policy | On |
| Anti-spam inbound policy (Default) | Always on |
| Connection filter policy (Default) | Always on |
| Anti-spam outbound policy (Default) | Always on |

This screenshot displays the **Microsoft Defender portal** within the **Anti-spam policies** configuration page.

**Context and Navigation:**

*   **Breadcrumb:** Policies & rules > Threat policies > Anti-spam policies.
*   **Page Title:** Anti-spam policies.
*   **Purpose:** "Use this page to configure policies that are included in anti-spam protection."
*   **Left Navigation Pane:** Displays organizational links, with the "Email & collaboration" section expanded, showing links such as Investigations, Explorer, Review, and Policies & rules.

**Action Bar and Active Element:**

*   The action bar contains the buttons **[+] Create policy** (with a dropdown chevron) and **Refresh**.
*   A contextual menu is expanded beneath the **Create policy** button.
*   **Menu Options:** The menu offers two policy types for creation: **Inbound** (currently highlighted) and **Outbound**.

**Policy List:**

*   A list of existing anti-spam policies is visible below the action bar, prefixed by selection checkboxes.
*   **Visible Policies Include:**
    *   Standard Preset Security Policy
    *   Anti-spam inbound policy (Default)
    *   Connection filter policy (Default)
    *   Anti-spam outbound policy (Default)

This image displays a dark-themed user interface for creating an anti-spam inbound policy within a security management platform, likely Microsoft 365 Defender, based on the breadcrumb and UI style.

**Context and Navigation (Top and Left Panels):**

*   **Breadcrumb:** Located at the top left, the navigation path is: `Policies & rules > Threat policies > Create anti-spam inbound policy`.
*   **Progress Stepper (Left Panel):** A vertical workflow indicates the steps for policy creation. The current step is highlighted in blue.
    1.  **Name your policy** (Current, selected)
    2.  Users, groups, and domains
    3.  Bulk email threshold & spam properties
    4.  Actions
    5.  Allow & block list
    6.  Review

**Main Content (Right Panel):**

*   **Header:** "Name your policy"
*   **Subtext:** "Add a name and description for your custom anti-spam policy."
*   **Input Fields:**
    *   **Name:** Labeled "Name \*" (indicating a required field). The input box contains the pre-filled text: `KnowBe4 Inbound Mail Security Integration`. This field is highlighted with a red/orange box and a blue underline, suggesting focus or required attention.
    *   **Description:** Labeled "Description." This is a large, empty text box for optional entry.

This image displays the configuration summary for the **Anti-spam inbound policy (Default)**, presented within a dark-themed UI.

**Policy Identification and Status:**
The policy is identified by a scroll icon and is listed as "Always on | Priority Lowest" (indicated by a green status dot).

**Sections and Settings:**
1.  **Bulk email threshold & spam properties:** This section is collapsed.
2.  **Actions:** This section is expanded, detailing the current policy responses:
    *   **Spam message action** and **Bulk message action** are set to "Move message to Junk Email folder".
    *   **High confidence spam message action** and **Phishing message action** are set to "Quarantine message" using the "DefaultFullAccessPolicy".
    *   **High confidence phishing message action** is set to "Quarantine message" using the more restrictive "AdminOnlyAccessPolicy".
    *   **Intra-Organizational messages to take action on** is set to "Default".
    *   **Enable spam safety tips**, **Enable for spam messages**, and **Enable for phishing messages** are all "On" (indicated by green status dots).
    *   The retention period is set for **Retain spam in quarantine for this many days** at "30".

The image concludes with a highlighted blue text button, **Edit actions**, used to modify the policy settings listed above.

This image displays a configuration panel titled "Actions" within a dark-mode user interface, designed for defining message handling policies based on threat type. The primary section title is "Message actions."

The panel is structured with multiple threat categories, each utilizing a dropdown menu to select an action:

1.  **Spam:** Action is set to "Move message to Junk Email folder."
2.  **High confidence spam:** Action is set to "Quarantine message." This section is followed by the policy selector: "Select quarantine policy," set to "DefaultFullAccessPolicy."
3.  **Phishing:** The input field for the Phishing action is active, displaying an open dropdown menu overlaying the lower sections. The menu presents six distinct action options:
    *   Move message to Junk Email folder
    *   Add X-header
    *   Prepend subject line with text
    *   Redirect message to email address
    *   Delete message
    *   Quarantine message (the current selection)
    *   This section is followed by a "Select quarantine policy" field, set to "AdminOnlyAccessPolicy."
4.  **Bulk complaint level (BCL) met or exceeded:** Action is set to "Move message to Junk Email folder."

At the bottom of the interface, two control buttons are present: a blue primary button labeled "Save" and a dark secondary button labeled "Cancel."

This image displays a configuration pane titled **"Actions"** within an administrative portal, presented in a dark theme. The panel governs message handling actions for various email threat categories.

**Key UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **General Structure:** The pane contains multiple sections, each defining an action (via a dropdown menu) for a specific type of threat or message characteristic.
2.  **Quarantine Policy:** The initial sections (likely Spam/Malware and Phishing) utilize a **"Select quarantine policy"** field, currently set to **"DefaultFullAccessPolicy."**
3.  **Phishing Actions:**
    *   **Phishing:** Action is set to **"Quarantine message."**
    *   **High confidence phishing:** This section is currently active, with its dropdown menu expanded.
        *   The currently displayed value is **"Quarantine message."**
        *   The open menu overlay provides three selectable options:
            1.  `Quarantine message`
            2.  `Move message to Junk Email folder`
            3.  `Redirect message to email address`
4.  **Other Actions Configured:**
    *   **Bulk complaint level (BCL) met or exceeded:** Action is set to **"Move message to Junk Email folder."**
    *   **Intra-Organizational messages to take action on:** Action is set to **"Default."**
5.  **Retention Setting:** An input field labeled **"Retain spam in quarantine for this many days"** is set to the value **"30."**
6.  **Action Buttons:** The pane concludes with two buttons in the footer: a primary, blue **"Save"** button, and a secondary **"Cancel"** button.

This image displays a dark-themed configuration screen for a feature titled **"Zero-hour auto purge (ZAP)"**.

**UI Elements and Configuration:**

1.  **Title:** The header text is **"Zero-hour auto purge (ZAP)"**.
2.  **Primary Control:** A checkbox labeled **"Enable zero-hour auto purge (ZAP)"** is present.
    *   It is currently checked (enabled).
    *   An information icon ($\text{i}$) follows the text, indicating the availability of contextual help or further details.
3.  **Subordinate Controls (Conditional Settings):** Two additional checkboxes follow, presumably dependent on the primary control being enabled:
    *   Checkbox 2: Labeled **"Enable for phishing messages"**. This is checked (enabled).
    *   Checkbox 3: Labeled **"Enable for spam messages"**. This is checked (enabled).

**Action Buttons:**

At the bottom of the interface, two action buttons are displayed:

1.  **Save:** A primary button, highlighted in solid blue, used to commit the changes.
2.  **Cancel:** A secondary button with a light grey background, used to discard changes and exit the configuration.

**Context:** The interface suggests a security or messaging application setting related to the automatic and immediate removal ("purge") of specific message types (phishing and spam).

This image is a screenshot of a dark-mode administrative configuration interface, specifically a submenu listing various "Rules."

**Context and UI:**
The interface presents five vertical menu items, each consisting of a blue icon, a menu title (left column), and a corresponding descriptive subtitle (right column). The main section title, **Rules**, is highlighted with a red rectangular border, indicating the current navigation path. The listed items are separated by thin horizontal dividers.

**Detailed Text and Elements (Top to Bottom):**

| Icon | Menu Title | Description | Emphasis |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| $\ominus$ (Stop/Minus) | **Tenant Allow/Block Lists** | Manage allow or block entries for your organization. | None |
| $\text{\small Key}$ (Key) | **Email authentication settings** | Settings for Authenticated Received Chain (ARC) and DKIM in your organization. | None |
| $\oplus\text{\small Arrow}$ (Forward) | **Advanced delivery** | Manage overrides for special system use cases. | None |
| $\text{\small Funnel}$ (Filter) | **Enhanced filtering** | Configure Exchange Online Protection (EOP) scanning to work correctly when your domain's MX record doesn't route email to EOP first. | None |
| $\text{\small Flow}$ (Flowchart) | **Quarantine policies** | Apply custom rules to quarantined messages by using default quarantine policies or creating your own. | Red border highlight |

The item **Quarantine policies** is visually emphasized with a red rectangular border, suggesting it is the currently selected or active element within the list.

The image displays a dark-themed administrative interface for configuring email quarantine policies. The context is the `Quarantine policy` page, accessible via the breadcrumb path `Policies & rules > Threat policies > Quarantine policy`. The main body shows a list of policies (e.g., `NotificationEnabledPolicy`) and action buttons including `+ Add custom policy`, `Refresh`, `Export`, and `Global settings`.

The primary focus is the **Quarantine notification settings** configuration pane, a flyout displayed on the right side of the screen, which is accessed by selecting the highlighted **Global settings** button.

The pane allows customization of email notifications sent to recipients for quarantined messages, containing the following configurable fields and settings:

1.  **Sender Configuration:**
    *   **Sender display name:** Text input field. Includes a note that the display name may be overridden by an existing active sender address.
    *   **Specify sender address:** Text input field, requiring an address from the organization's domain.
2.  **Content Customization:**
    *   **Subject:** Text input field.
    *   **Disclaimer:** Multi-line text input field.
3.  **Language and Review:**
    *   **Choose language:** Dropdown set to `English_USA`. A button labeled `Add` is present.
    *   Instructional text: "Click the language to show the previously configured settings."
4.  **Branding:**
    *   **Use my company logo:** Checkbox option. The description notes that this replaces the Microsoft logo and includes an informational warning about needing to upload the company logo via documentation link.
5.  **Notification Frequency:**
    *   **Send end-user spam notifications:** Dropdown selection, currently set to `Daily`.

The pane concludes with standard administrative buttons: `Save` and `Cancel`.

This image displays a configuration summary page for a policy named **NotificationEnabledPolicy** within a dark-mode user interface.

**Header and Navigation:**
The primary identifier at the top is the policy name: **NotificationEnabledPolicy**. In the top right corner, standard window controls (up arrow, down arrow, X) are visible.

**Policy Details:**
The policy parameters are organized into categories:

1.  **Name:** NotificationEnabledPolicy
2.  **When Changed:** 2024-09-23T14:01:13.0000000+00:00
3.  **User message access:** Lists the following permitted actions:
    *   release the message from quarantine
    *   block sender
    *   delete the message
    *   preview the message
4.  **Quarantine notification:** This setting is configured as **Enabled with messages from blocked sender addresses excluded.**

A screenshot depicting a user interface panel, likely from a security or messaging management system, displayed in a dark theme.

**Title/Header (Highlighted):**
The panel title is clearly visible and highlighted with an orange bounding box: `DefaultFullAccessWithNotificationPolicy`.

**Content Breakdown:**
The body of the panel lists policy settings in a key-value format:

1.  **Name:** `DefaultFullAccessWithNotificationPolicy`
2.  **User message access:** (A list of permissions allowing users to interact with quarantined messages)
    *   `release the message from quarantine`
    *   `delete the message`
    *   `preview the message`
    *   `allow sender`
3.  **Quarantine notification:** (A section header, partially obscured by an orange arrow pointing left)
    *   Status/Description: `Enabled with messages from blocked sender addresses excluded.`

**UI Elements:**
The upper right corner shows standard window control icons: an 'Up' arrow, a 'Down' arrow, and an 'X' (close button).

**Annotation:**
A prominent, thick orange arrow points directly to the `Quarantine notification` header, indicating the focus of the capture.

This image displays a step-by-step wizard interface for configuring a **New policy**, presented in a dark theme. The current step in the workflow is **Recipient message access**.

### Context and Navigation

The left navigation pane outlines the four policy creation steps:
1.  **Policy name** (Completed, indicated by a blue checkmark).
2.  **Recipient message access** (Active step, indicated by a solid blue circle).
3.  **Quarantine notification** (Pending).
4.  **Summary** (Pending).

### Recipient Message Access Configuration

The main panel is titled **Recipient message access** and includes descriptive text and configuration options:

**Recipient message access (Required field)**:
*   **Limited access:** (Unselected radio button). Description: "Recipients can view quarantined messages, but they cannot release messages from the quarantine state."
*   **Set specific access (Advanced):** (Selected radio button). Description: "Specify exactly what recipients can do with quarantined messages."

**Select release action preference:**
*   A dropdown menu is present with the selection: "Allow recipients to request a message to be released from quarantine."

**Select additional actions recipients can take on quarantined messages:**
A group of four checkboxes are all enabled (checked):
*   Delete
*   Preview
*   Block sender
*   Allow sender

images.alt:
This image depicts a configuration screen within a dark-mode user interface for creating a **"New policy"**. The interface is structured as a two-column wizard.

**Left Panel (Policy Creation Progress):**
A vertical navigation pane tracks the policy creation steps.
*   **Completed Steps (Checked):** "Policy name" and "Recipient message access."
*   **Current Active Step (Solid Blue Indicator):** "Quarantine notification."
*   **Pending Step (Unchecked):** "Summary."

**Right Panel (Configuration Details):**
The header for this section is **"Quarantine notification."** Configuration options include:
1.  **Checkbox:** Labeled **"Enable."** (The control is currently checked, indicating the feature is active.)
2.  **Radio Buttons:** Two mutually exclusive options defining the scope of the notification when the feature is enabled.
    *   **Option 1 (Unselected):** "Include quarantined messages from blocked sender addresses."
    *   **Option 2 (Selected):** **"Don't include quarantined messages from blocked sender addresses."**

This is a screenshot of a "New policy" creation wizard, presented on a dark theme interface.

The screen is divided into two main vertical panels:

**Left Panel: Policy Creation Steps (Wizard Progression)**

This panel shows a progress tracker with four steps, three of which are marked complete with blue checkmarks, and the final step is currently selected (blue solid circle):

1.  **Policy name** (Complete)
2.  **Recipient message access** (Complete)
3.  **Quarantine notification** (Complete)
4.  **Summary** (Current step)

**Right Panel: Review policy**

This panel displays the configured settings for review, categorized under three main headings. Each section includes an "Edit" link for modification:

1.  **Tag name**
    *   Name: `Unified Quarantine`
    *   `Edit` (Link)

2.  **User message access**
    *   Recipient can:
        *   `request to release the message from quarantine`
        *   `block sender`
        *   `delete the message`
        *   `preview the message`
        *   `allow sender`
    *   `Edit` (Link)

3.  **Quarantine notification**
    *   Enabled: `Enabled with messages from blocked sender addresses excluded.`
    *   `Edit` (Link)

**Bottom Navigation**

The bottom of the screen features a footer with navigation buttons:

*   A dark gray button labeled **Back**.
*   A primary blue button labeled **Submit**.

images.alt:
This image displays a dark-mode email notification for a **Microsoft 365 Security Phish Alert**.

**Header:**
The top banner reads: `[Phish Alert] Microsoft 365 security: You have messages in quarantine`.

**Primary Content Block (Quarantine Summary):**
*   **Branding:** Features the Microsoft logo and name.
*   **Title:** `Review These Messages`
*   **Summary Text:** `1 messages are being held for you to review as of 7/21/2025 5:21:38 PM (UTC).`
*   **Confidentiality:** A section of text below the timestamp is intentionally blurred (redacted).

**Secondary Content Block (Quarantined Message Details):**
*   **Title:** `Prevented phish messages`
*   **Message Data:**
    *   Sender: (Blurred/Redacted)
    *   Subject: `Advising meeting`
    *   Date: `7/21/2025 3:02:16 PM`
*   **Action Buttons (UI Elements):**
    *   `Review Message` (Primary button, blue background)
    *   `Release` (Secondary button)
    *   `Block Sender` (Secondary button)

**Footer:**
*   **Copyright:** `© 2025 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.`
*   **Links (Blue Hypertext):**
    *   `Privacy Statement`
    *   `Acceptable Use Policy`
